NRI:FND: Collaborative Mobile Manufacturing in Uncertain Scenarios
Welcome to Our Project
Tell Me More

About

Large-scale manufacturing is common practice in several industries: transportation, maritime, energy, aerospace and construction. Finishing operations, such as trimming, sanding and painting, are necessary to guarantee tolerances and required properties are met. For humans, those tasks are stressful, and may lead to physical discomfort and potential for repetitive strain injury. To improve safety for human workers and the quality of work for finishing operations on large-scale parts, a team of autonomous mobile robots, assisted by human supervisors, can be deployed.

Objective

Establish and demonstrate novel strategies for collaborative robotic systems performing post-processing operations (trimming and sanding), on large scale fiber-reinforced polymer parts without part re-positioning.

Timeline

Septemebr 2020 - August 2021

Funding Support

This project is supported by NSF:CMMI, Award Number:2024795.

Work Packages

The objective of this project is to design a distributed intelligent architecture for teams of mobile robots to perform finishing operations under human supervision.
Sensing and Localization
Robot navigation
Control and Planning
Multi-robot triming and sanding
Cognitive System
Task completion
Manufacturing
Wind blades

  • Date: January 2020

  • Category: Illustration

Autonomous collaborative sensing

For environment characterization and localization

We propose a framework to harvest the aggregated perception capabilities of several mobile robots for enabling efficient, dynamic, and real-time identification of critical surface features. In this context, a team of robots will coordinate and evenly distribute their efforts for mapping the environment, resulting in a real-time complete and dense 3D reconstruction of the part to be manipulated

Collaborative Planning And Control

For a mobile robotic manipulator team

To perform the finishing operations on large-scale parts, a team of robots will plan and execute motion and interaction tasks. In this project, we propose the development of a fully decentralized strategy based on rectangular map decomposition where the planning capabilities are informed by the control characteristics.

Cognitive System For Task Completion

Task completion

In this work, we will leverage the avenues of robotic validation and human-operator validation for task completion. Specifically, we are interested in the robotic system to understand when the finishing task has been completed. To achieve this, we propose to develop a local-based evaluation methodology from information gathered from robot understanding and human experience. A combination of DNN algorithms and fiducial marker detection will be used locally at each agent to evaluate the completion of the task.
